attributes.title: Physical stock take
attributes.description:
·       A physical stock take was conducted on 18.03.2025 to evaluate the effectiveness of internal controls and to confirm whether the physical stock items corresponded with the records in SAP.

·       It was noted that there were items with variations however others had immaterial variances as seen:

ü  Bread stock had -127.5 pieces

ü  Polybags had -262 pieces

ü  Crates had nil variation.

ü  Raw materials had immaterial variances as seen below:

·       Below is the summary of the findings:

Table 1:Stock take summary.
attributes.recommendation:
·       The branch management should put more controls to ensure proper recording of stock items to minimise variations.

·       Deductions also should be raised and submitted on time.
attributes.effect: Variations noted implies that there were lapses in accurate recording of stock items, there is need to strengthen controls.

value: ·    There was a pending deduction of excess market damages of 99 pieces which I was still waiting to analyse with the supervisors before good issue was raised.We will do a follow up to check the negative variations in polybags.

·   There was a pending deduction of excess market damages of 99 pieces which manager was still waiting to analyse with the supervisors before good issue was raised.We will do a follow up to check the negative variations in polybags.

In the prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, it was noted that Bread stock had -77 pieces, Polybags had +847.3pieces, White flour had -6.38 kgs, crates had -7, utto had +5.19 litre, white ingredient had -0.13 kgs, yeast had -0.87 Kgs.
Current

attributes.title: Bread weights
attributes.description:
·       Weight Check on bread produced and packed in the branch was done on a random basis to determine whether bread dispatched to the market was of the recommended weight as Per KEBS requirement.

·       From the audit sample underweights were as seen below:

ü  400 CTW had 29%

ü  600 BT had 1%

ü  600 Barrel had 29%

·       Below is the detailed summary of the audit findings:

Table 2:Bread weight check.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should enhance supervision of production workers to ensure correct production procedures are followed to ensure bread produced is of correct weights.
attributes.effect: Cases of underweight exposes the company to fines and legal actions for violating laws on product weights, it can also trigger KEBS Scrutiny leading to increased inspections and this can affect the company operations.

value: ·     There is slight improvement in weights, we are still working on the remaining % to ensure 100% correct weight, we are pushing dividers to be keen, oven men to ensure baking time is correct and slicers to achieve efficiency to minimise issues of overcooling leading to underweights.

·     There is slight improvement in weights, we are still working on the remaining % to ensure 100% correct weight, we are pushing dividers to be keen, oven men to ensure baking time is correct and slicers to achieve efficiency to minimise issues of overcooling leading to underweights.

·       In prior audit dated 22/02/2025, underweight cases were noted across all bread varieties as seen:

ü  400 ctw had 21%

ü  400g butter had 36%

ü  400 barrel white 56 %

ü  600 barrel 15%
Current

attributes.title: Bread Damages
attributes.description:
·       Analysis of bread damages was done for a period of 28 days from 19 February-18 March 2025 to determine whether production and Market damages were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% and 0.5% of total production and sales respectively.

·       It was noted that production damages stood at 0.26% of total production with a cost implication of Kshs. 12,561.31 while market damages stood at 0.58% of total sales with a cost implication of Kshs 16,377.66 which was above the standard threshold as illustrated below:

Table 3:Production Damages analysis.

 N/B. The analysis is exclusive of 1,717 oven Damages.

Table 4:Market Damages.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure correct production procedures is adhered to ensure bread of good quality is produced to minimise excess damages caused
attributes.effect: Both production and market damages exceeded the allowable threshold by 0.06 % and 0.08% of total production and sales respectively, with this the company incurred an extra cost of KES 28,938.97.

value: ·    Market damages was mainly contributed by faulty slicing machine which caused bread deformities before being sent to the market, the issue is already addressed the machine was taken to the workshop going forward we will minimise.Production damages was contributed by breakdown of MBN 118 oven to an extend have contributed to more damages.

·  Market damages was mainly contributed by faulty slicing machine which caused bread deformities before being sent to the market, the issue is already addressed the machine was taken to the workshop going forward we will minimise.Production damages was contributed by breakdown of MBN 118 oven to an extend have contributed to more damages.
In a prior audit report dating 22/02/2025, average production damage stood at 0.28% while market damages were 0.58%.
Current

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of both Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries were done for a period of 28 days from 19 February 2025-18 March 2025, to find out the branch’s utto consumption, average yield, branch production capacity Utilization and to check if there are any instances of remixes.

·       The audit findings were as seen below:

Ø  Average yield per bag was 190.92 loaves per bag.

Ø  Utto consumption was at 100%.

Ø  2,220 cases of remixes noted

Ø  Average production was 73.89 bags per day representing 91.22% of target achievement which is 81 bags.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;

Table 5:Mixing Chart analysis.
attributes.recommendation:
·       In case of breakdown in the branch, the manager should scale down on mixing of flour to control the number of remixes in the branch

·       Sales team should put extra effort to onboard more customers to ensure branch production capacity is fully utilized.

value: ·      The production target achievement is affected on market trends, which indicate low demand; therefore, production is controlled accordingly. The yield is acceptable and within the Branch BOM, with contributions from Grande and Mini loaf.Remixes occurred due to generator breakdowns and overheating, despite reducing the number of ovens, as well as prolonged power outages.

·      The production target achievement is affected on market trends, which indicate low demand; therefore, production is controlled accordingly. The yield is acceptable and within the Branch BOM, with contributions from Grande and Mini loaf.Remixes occurred due to generator breakdowns and overheating, despite reducing the number of ovens, as well as prolonged power outages.

·  In a prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, utto consumption was at a ratio of 1:1, average yield for January was 191.01 loaves per bag and average production for the period 08/01/25-31/01/25 was 74.96 bags per day representing 69.41% of target achievement which is 108 bags while for February 01/02/25-19/02/25 average production was 76.63 bags representing 94.61% of the target of 81 bags.There was a total of 3592 cases of remixes.
Current

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
· An analysis of branch optimal utilization of Production workers was done   for period of 28 days from 19 February 2025-18 March 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.3 bags per worker.

·       It was noted that the production efficiency was 4.3 bags per production worker which was okey as  illustrated in the table below:

Table 6:Production efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management to maintain production efficiency and even improve further.
attributes.effect: Production workers achieved their set KPI, to be maintained.

value: We will keep up with the production efficiency and even improve further.
We will keep up with the production efficiency and even improve further.
In a prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, it was noted that production efficiency was at 4.19 bags per worker.
Current
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
·       Packing efficiency was calculated for a period of 28 days from 19 February 2025-18 March 2025.The aim was to determine if the packers hired were achieving the set packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

·       It was noted that the average packing efficiency was 89.94 crates per packer as illustrated below;

Table 7:Packing Efficiency.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should promptly report to KAF whenever there are breakdowns and send reminders to ensure issues are resolved promptly to reduce extra costs incurred for hiring extra workers.
attributes.effect: Average packing efficiency was below the set target, the company hired 21 extra workers with a cost Implication of KES 19,152.

value: Unachieved packing efficiency was affected by frequent slicing machine breakdown (Faulty slicing machine) hence the manager had to employ extra slicer.
Unachieved packing efficiency was affected by frequent slicing machine breakdown (Faulty slicing machine) hence the manager had to employ extra slicer.
In a prior audit report, dated 22/02/2025, the average packing efficiency was 89.34 crates per Packer,48 extra workers were hired.
Current

attributes.title: Debtors analysis.
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of Outstanding debtors was done as at 18 March 2025 to determine if there were long outstanding debts that were posing risk of bad debts to the company.

·       A total of Kshs 315,730.59 debtors were noted that there was one customer who was blacklisted with a balance of Kshs. 4,086. Most of this were balances due to institutions however there were also route customers who had balances as illustrated below in Appendix 2.
attributes.recommendation: ·    A follow up should be made by sales rep to ensure customers with debt do pay and clear while those with security deposit the same is used to offset outstanding balances
attributes.effect: Customers with debts exposes the company to risk of losing its revenue if do not have security deposit to cover up for the outstanding balances.

value: All debts are under sales rep follow up they are aware; we will do a follow up to ensure these balances are cleared.
All debts are under sales rep follow up they are aware; we will do a follow up to ensure these balances are cleared.

·   In the prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, It was noted that there was one customer who was blacklisted with a balance of Kshs.4,086 and one institution with a balance of kshs. 7,730 who had not been supplied for 5 months other debtors balances were those of institutions and others whose security deposit, supa-points and extra cent was above the debt.
Current

attributes.title: Mini-shop Spot check
attributes.description:
·       A Spot check was carried out at the mini shop on 18 March 2025, to verify if operations were being conducted in line with established standards.

·    A variance of 171 which was attributed to transaction costs was noted and there was a customer who had paid a kshs 9,417 previous day and was supplied with bread on day of spot check illustrated below:

Table 8:Mini shop spot check.
attributes.recommendation: Mini shop controls working effectively to be maintained.
attributes.effect: Mini shop is well controlled.

value: ·       The variations were attributed to transaction costs, Customer advance payments should be discouraged.
The variations were attributed to transaction costs, Customer advance payments should be discouraged.
·    In the prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, a Variance between expected sales and expected cash of +12 was noted which was due to a customer who had paid more.
Current

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A spot check in the cash office was carried out on 19/03/2025 with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

·       It was noted that all the cash was well accounted for there were nil variations. The expected cash was Kshs.140,434 as per cashflow number 322253 agreed with cash at hand as at 19//03/2025.
attributes.recommendation: Cash controls are working effectively to be maintained.

value: Proper recording and frequent stock checks
Proper recording and frequent stock checks
In prior audit dated 22/02/2025, It was noted that all the cash was well accounted for there were nil variations. The expected cash was Kshs.243,151 Agreed to the cash at hand as at Date 21/02/2025.
Current

attributes.title: Vehicle fuel consumption
attributes.description:
·       Fuel consumption analysis was done for a period of 28 days from 01/02/2025-28/02/2025 to determine whether the standard mileage set for each vehicle was being met.

·       From the analysis it was noted that fuel consumption was within the range, however Tuktuk for Imara II had faulty mileage readings, as illustrated below in Appendix 1.
attributes.recommendation:
·  Allocation should be done as per the allowable standard consumption rates.

·    Vehicles with faulty mileage should be sent to the workshop for repair.
attributes.effect: Vehicle using more fuel than set standard implies that the company was incurring more than set budget. Further using vehicle with faulty speedometer implies that the manager will not in position to control fuel which is issued on daily basis.

value: We will keep up with proper fuel allocation/correct records.
Manager is advised to keep up with proper fuel allocation/correct records.

In a prior audit report dated 22/02/2025, it was noted that there were Vehicles that were consuming fuel more than the standard rate i.e. Imara 1 which had faulty mileage readings but had consumed more and Mlolongo had also consumed more litres. It was also noted Tuktuk supplying Kamakis had faulty mileage and was with KAF.
Current
Operations/Production Department
